bestBHT.bht: The iniquity of Israel accumulated until it reached its full extent in the generation, enacting the collective vengeance of Heaven. This represents God's purpose, and the verse mentions the blood shed by prophets, such as Abel, the first prophet foreshadowing the sacrifice of Christ. Ultimately, this generation will face visible and terrible punishment as God demands justice for the shedding of prophets' blood and the righteousness of the slain.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: As it was only in the last generation of them that "the iniquity of the Amorites was full" and then the abominations of ages were at once completely and awfully avenged, so the iniquity of Israel was allowed to accumulate from age to age till in that generation it came to the full, and the whole collected vengeance of Heaven broke at once over its devoted head.
In the first French Revolution the same awful principle was exemplified, and Christendom has not done with it yet.
Archibald T. Robertson: Divinely ordered sequence, first aorist passive subjunctive of εκζητεω, a late and rare verb outside of LXX and N.T., requiring as a debt the blood of the prophets.
If the present passive is accepted, it means the blood which is perpetually shed from time to time.
It is a bold metaphor for the purpose of God.
John Gill: The blood of all the prophets,.... The same with 'all the righteous blood', or the blood of all the righteous men, in Matthew 23:35, which was shed from the foundation of the world.

Abel, the son of the first man, and who was the first whose blood was shed, was not only a righteous man, but a prophet; for by the sacrifice which he offered up, he gave a prophetical hint of the sacrifice of Christ.

Just as in Babylon will be found, when God makes inquisition for blood, as he sooner or later always does, the blood of the prophets and saints, and of all that are slain upon earth, ever since Rome papal has been in power.
John Wesley: The blood of all shall be required of this generation — That is, shall be visibly and terribly punished upon it.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 11:50, it is explained that the iniquity of Israel was allowed to accumulate until it reached its full extent in that generation, resulting in the collective vengeance of Heaven being unleashed upon them. This concept is likened to the events of the first French Revolution and serves as a bold metaphor for God's purpose. The verse speaks of the blood of prophets, highlighting the divine debt owed for their shedding. This includes the blood of Abel, the first prophet who foreshadowed the sacrifice of Christ. Ultimately, the punishment for the shedding of this blood will be visibly and terribly inflicted upon the generation in question, as God demands justice.

The iniquity of Israel was allowed to accumulate until it reached its full extent in that generation, resulting in the collective vengeance of Heaven being unleashed. This concept is a bold metaphor for God's purpose. The verse speaks of the blood shed by prophets, including Abel, who foreshadowed the sacrifice of Christ. Ultimately, the punishment for shedding this blood will be visibly and terribly inflicted upon the generation, as God demands justice for the prophets and the righteous.

The iniquity of Israel accumulated until it reached its full extent in the generation, enacting the collective vengeance of Heaven. This represents God's purpose, and the verse mentions the blood shed by prophets, such as Abel, the first prophet foreshadowing the sacrifice of Christ. Ultimately, this generation will face visible and terrible punishment as God demands justice for the shedding of prophets' blood and the righteousness of the slain.

The iniquity of Israel reached its full extent in that generation, resulting in the collective vengeance of Heaven being unleashed. This aligns with the concept seen in the first French Revolution, showcasing God's ongoing principle. The verse speaks of the blood shed by prophets, including Abel, the first righteous man and prophet who foreshadowed the sacrifice of Christ. The punishment for shedding this blood will be visibly and terribly inflicted upon the generation, as God demands justice for all the righteous and prophets.

The iniquity of Israel reached its full extent, resulting in the collective vengeance of Heaven. This aligns with the concept seen in the first French Revolution, showcasing God's ongoing principle. The verse speaks of the blood shed by prophets, including Abel, the first righteous man and prophet. The punishment for shedding this blood will be visibly and terribly inflicted upon the generation, as God demands justice for all the righteous and prophets.
